author: Lauren_Mills
title: Lauren_Mills published Barratt builds strong sales and profits
text:
Comments (0) 
​Housebuilder Barratt Developments shrugged off Brexit uncertainty with a healthy set of full-year results. 
The Coalville based developer said the average selling price of its homes rose more than 10 per cent in 2016, to £289,800, showing house hunters remain keen to secure deals. 
Barratt said pre-tax profits jumped 20.7 per cent £682.3 million for the year to the end of June. The number of homes it built also increased, from 16,447 to 17,319, a rise of 5.3 per cent. 
Building on its strong performance, the stock market listed company said the new financial year had got off to a "positive start", with an increase in private home reservations compared to the same time last year. 
Read more: Exclusive interview with Barratt CEO David Thomas 
Barratt chief executive David Thomas said: "The strong operational and financial performance in FY16 reinforces the progress we have made over the last few years as does our disciplined volume growth. 
"This was underpinned by our fast asset turn model and our industry leading customer service and construction excellence. 
"Barratt starts the new financial year in a good position with a strong balance sheet, good forward sales and an experienced management team. 
"Whilst we continue to monitor market conditions closely, current trading trends are positive, and I remain confident in the fundamentals of the housing sector and of our business." 
Despite Barratt's strong performance, its shares slipped 1.2 per cent to 500.50p in early trading, down from 568p on the morning of the June 23 referendum. The shares are however making a steady rise back towards their pre-vote levels as market confidence returns.
